block-definition.comment: Connect to a broker The options are not required but can be filled if needed 1. username (some brokers need this) 2. password (some brokers need this) 3. keepalive (default time is 60 seconds but some brokers need a shorter time) 4. connection callback (ringed set of scripts to be run when connection is made or remade) ADVANCED: The brokers offered in the menu are accessed using default ports and basepaths (if needed). If accessing other brokers, the complete urls should be formed like this: siteURL:port/basepath e.g mqtt.eclipseprojects.io:443/mqtt It is possible to have more than one connection to the same broker, for instance, using two different user/pass accounts simultaneously. To do this, add a connection id at the end of the broker: e.g mqtt.eclipseprojects.io:443/mqtt|1

block-definition.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %'broker' topic %'topic' $nl on each message run %'callback' %'options'
block-definition.comment: Subscribe to a topic on a broker Make sure you have already run an MQTT connect block before using this one You should add a script to be run inside he grey ring. It will be run each time a message is received If you click on the arrow on the grey ring twice, you can use #1 and #2 inside your script. #1 will contain the received payload #2 will contain the received topic name The options are not required but can be filled if needed 1. Subscribed QoS (0,1 or 2) Note this will be downgraded if it exceeds the QoS of the stored message held on the broker 2. Binary mode (boolean) Default (false) - payload is returned as text If true, payload returned as single column list of values in the range of 0 to 255..

Publish a message to an MQTT broker The options are not required but can be filled if needed 1. QoS (quality of service 0,1 or 2 - see https://www.emqx.com/en/blog/introduction-to-mqtt-qos) 2. Retain flag (boolean) 3. Binary mode (boolean). Default (false) - the payload is published as text If set to true then payload is expected to be a single column list of values in the 0 to 255 range and is published to the broker as a buffer of bytes. Note: If the payload is a list and you don't set the buffer mode option, it will be automatically be converted into JSON and sent as text.

block-definition.s: enable move custom block to top

block.l: if( !CustomCommandBlockMorph.prototype._userMenu){ CustomCommandBlockMorph.prototype._userMenu = CustomCommandBlockMorph.prototype.userMenu; } CustomCommandBlockMorph.prototype.userMenu = function(){ var shiftClicked = world.currentKey === 16 ,menu = this._userMenu(); menu.addItem( "move block to top", function (){ var rcvr = this.scriptTarget(), ide = this.parentThatIsA(IDE_Morph), def = this.isGlobal ? this.definition : rcvr.getMethod(this.blockSpec), spec = def.spec; if (this.isGlobal) { ide.stage.globalBlocks = ide.stage.globalBlocks.filter(item => item !== def); ide.stage.globalBlocks.unshift(def); } else { rcvr.customBlocks = rcvr.customBlocks.filter(item => item !== def); rcvr.customBlocks.unshift(def); } ide.flushPaletteCache(); ide.refreshPalette(); ide.recordUnsavedChanges(); } ); return menu; }

if( !CustomReporterBlockMorph.prototype._userMenu){ CustomReporterBlockMorph.prototype._userMenu = CustomReporterBlockMorph.prototype.userMenu; } CustomReporterBlockMorph.prototype.userMenu = function(){ var shiftClicked = world.currentKey === 16 ,menu = this._userMenu(); menu.addItem( "move block to top", function (){ var rcvr = this.scriptTarget(), ide = this.parentThatIsA(IDE_Morph), def = this.isGlobal ? this.definition : rcvr.getMethod(this.blockSpec), spec = def.spec; if (this.isGlobal) { ide.stage.globalBlocks = ide.stage.globalBlocks.filter(item => item !== def); ide.stage.globalBlocks.unshift(def); } else { rcvr.customBlocks = rcvr.customBlocks.filter(item => item !== def); rcvr.customBlocks.unshift(def); } ide.flushPaletteCache(); ide.refreshPalette(); ide.recordUnsavedChanges(); } ); return menu; }

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s

inputs.input: allall broker.emqx.io mqtt.eclipseprojects.io test.mosquitto.org broker.xmqtt.net broker.hivemq.com

block-definition.comment: Options: 1. Sub binary mode (boolean) Default (false) - received payload is returned as text. If true then subscribed, received payload is returned as single column list of values in the range of 0 to 255.. Default (false) - it is returned as text 2. Pub binary mode (boolean). Default (false) - the payload is published as text. If set to true then published payload is expected to be a single column list of values in the 0 to 255 range and is published to the broker as a buffer of bytes. Note: If the payload is a list and you don't set the buffer mode option, it will be automatically be converted into JSON and sent as text

input.expand: sub binary mode pub binary mode

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s

block-definition.s: $cloudOutline MQTT request %'broker' topic %'topic' $nl response topic %'rtopic' payload %'payload' $nl on response run %'callback' %'options'
block-definition.comment: The options are not required but can be filled if needed. 1. Append response topic (boolean): If true, the response topic is added at the end of the call topic after @ sign. The default condition (true) response topic is added. 2. Sub binary mode (boolean) Default (false) - received payload is returned as text. If true,then the subscribed, received payload is returned as a single column list of values in the range of 0 to 255.. 3. Pub binary mode (boolean). Default (false) - the payload is published as text. If set to true then published payload is expected to be a single column list of values in the 0 to 255 range and is published to the broker as a buffer of bytes. Note: If the payload is a list and you don't set the buffer mode option, it will be automatically be converted into JSON and sent as text

input.expand: append response topic sub binary mode pub binary mode

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s

block-definition.s: $cloudOutline MQTT example response reporter payload %'payload' topic %'topic'
block-definition.comment: This is a simple echo example. Topic can be used to filter the response.

block-definition.s: $cloudOutline MQTT request %'broker' topic %'topic' $nl response topic %'rtopic' payload %'payload' %'options'
block-definition.comment: The response topic should be a unique value for each call e.g. use timer The options are not required but can be filled if needed 1. Timeout value - default is 3 seconds 2. Append response topic (boolean): If true, the response topic is added at the end of the call topic after @ sign. The default condition (true) response topic is added. 3. Sub binary mode (boolean) Default (false) - received payload is returned as text. If true, subscribed, received payload returned as single column list of values in the range of 0 to 255.. Default (false) - it is returned as text 4. Pub binary mode (boolean). Default (false) - the payload is published as text. If set to true then published payload is expected to be a single column list of values in the 0 to 255 range and is published to the broker as a buffer of bytes. Note: If the payload is a list and you don't set the buffer mode option, it will be automatically be converted into JSON and sent as text

input.expand: timeout append response topic sub binary mode pub binary mode

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s

block-definition.comment: Open (edit) this block to look at examples how to use the MQTT Extension blocks Background documentation: https://github.com/pixavier/mqtt4snap Last source code version (mqtt.xml and mqttExtension.js): https://gitlab.com/cymplecy/Snap/-/tree/master/libraries

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s
$cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s

scripts.comment: Step 1: Activate the responder as a simple subscription

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT request %s topic %s %br response topic %s payload %mlt %mult%s

scripts.comment: Step 2: Send a request and wait the answer.
To execute the examples, single click on blocks, following the corresponding steps.
Step 2 bis: Send a request and do not wait for the answer
Synchronous client-server Hello World! with dynamic response topic (timer)

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT request %s topic %s %br response topic %s payload %mlt %mult%s

scripts.comment: Step 2: Send a request (timer acts as idCall) and wait for the answer
Asynchronous client-server Hello World! with dynamic response topic (timer)

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT request %s topic %s %br response topic %s payload %mlt %br on response run %cmdRing %mult%s

scripts.comment: Step 2 bis: Send a request (timer acts as idCall) and do not wait for the answer

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT example response reporter payload %mlt topic %txt

scripts.comment: Asynchronous client-server Hello World! with static response topic (name2)

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT request %s topic %s %br response topic %s payload %mlt %br on response run %cmdRing %mult%s

scripts.comment: Synchronous client-server Hello World! with static response topic (name2)

block-definition.comment: Modify V10 variadic defaults to be able to work for blank and psuedo (false/true) boolean entries Blank defaults are set as zero width spaces which are removed when block is executed This is needed for the connect block The options are then checked to see if they should be boolean and if they are not aready a boolean value, then they are replaced with boolean true if default is text "true", otherwise boolean false.
Encode costume, sound or data to Base64
Decode costume, sound or data from Base64

custom-block.s: $cloudOutline MQTT subscribe to %s topic %s %br on each message run %cmdRing %mult%s
